We have determined this work to be in the public domain in the United
States of America. It may not be in the public domain in other countries.
Copies are provided as a preservation service. Particularly outside of the
United States, persons receiving copies should make appropriate efforts to
determine the copyright status of the work in their country and use the
work accordingly. It is possible that current copyright holders, heirs or
the estate of the authors of individual portions of the work, such as
illustrations or photographs, assert copyrights over these portions.
Depending on the nature of subsequent use that is made, additional rights
may need to be obtained independently of anything we can address.

 ^PREFATORY NOTE 
 
 This eighty-seventh yearly issue of The English Catalogue of Books comprises 
 the titles (under authors, and subjects or titles) of works published during 1923, 
 and also of some received too late for inclusion in the eighty-sixth issue. 
 
 The main entry for each book begins with the author's surname (if known) 
 in heavy type. As an index to these " Author " records, entries are also made 
 under the titles, commencing with their most important words (which usually 
 indicate the subjects with which the books deal), or with the first words. Many 
 other index entries are also made under subjects in order to make the Catalogue 
 of use to persons in search of the literature of a particular topic, as well as to 
 those requiring a particular book. The name or word under which the main 
 entry appears is printed in italics in these index entries, thus giving a reference 
 to the place where the full information about a book may be found. Main 
 entries and index entries are in one alphabet. 
 
 e.g. 
 
 Writers with compound names are entered under the first part of the name, 
 
 Ashley-Cooper (F. S.) 
 
 and accordingly must be looked for in that order. References are also made, 
 however, from the last part of the name. 
 
 The publications of learned Societies are recorded in an Appendix. 
 
 The names and addresses of the Publishers of Great Britain and Ireland, 
 followed by those of the principal publishers in the United States and Canada, 
 will be found at the end of the volume. The telegraphic and cable addresses 
 and telephone numbers have been added when known. 
 
 Particulars of a number of British Agents of American and Colonial 
 publishers have been added to the names of the firms they represent. 
 
 Following the Preface is an analysis of the books of the year 1922, showing 
 in detail the number of works in each class of literature, and giving the proportions 
 of new books, translations, pamphlets, and new editions. 
 
 Every effort has been made to obtain the full particulars of the books noted. 
 Special enquiries were made in every case where information was deficient ; and 
 most publishers courteously responded. In the cases where entries have been 
 included without prices, the fault lies with the^publishers concerned. 
 
 Hearty thanks are due to the many publishers, secretaries, librarians, authors 
 and bibliographers who have assisted in making this book more correct and 
 comprehensive than it would have been otherwise. 
 
 The Editor will be glad to have particulars (author, title, size, price, publisher, 
 and month of publication) of any work which may have been omitted. Information 
 regarding each book should be given on a separate slip of paper or postcard. 
 It should be addressed to The Editor of The English Catalogue of Books, 
 “ Publishers' Circular " Office, iq, Adam Street. Strand, London, W.C.2. 
 
 541987 
 
 February, 1924. 
 
 The Editor. 
 


## p. (#6) ##################################################



## p. (#7) ##################################################

ANALYSIS OF BOOKS 
 
 PUBLISHED DURING 1923 IN THE UNITED KINGDOM 
 
 The Publishers' Circular records a total 
 of 12,274 books as having been published 
 in the United Kingdom during the year 
 1923. 
 
 This is an increase of 1,432 over the 
 total for 1922, and places the year 1923 
 second only to the “ peak ” year of 1913 
 in the history of British publishing. It 
 now may be said that, so far as volume 
 of output is concerned, British publishing 
 has entirely recovered from the effects of 
 the war and its consequent economic 
 depressions. 
 
 The accompanying statistical table is in 
 two parts : the first showing the number 
 of publications issued during the year in 
 each class of literature, with details of 
 new books, translations, pamphlets, and 
 new editions; and the second part shows 
 their monthly distribution. 
 
 The year’s increase of 1,432 is made up 
 of 492 new books and 940 new editions. 
 Actual new British books are 431 up; 
 translations have increased by 83; while 
 pamphlets are practically stationary with 
 a slight drop of 22. 
 
 The signs noted last year that the pub¬ 
 lishing “ seasons ” were coming back 
 with renewed vigour (after a year or two 
 of more uniform monthly distribution) are 
 fully confirmed by this year’s figures. A 
 glance at the second part of the table will 
 leave no doubt as to the reality of the 
 “ autumn publishing season,” no fewer 
 than 4,017 books having seen the light 
 during September to November. The 
 “ spring publishing season ” has not yet 
 become so marked as in former years, and 
 it has shifted from March to May. This 
 intense seasonal concentration of book 
 production may be good business for the 
 publishers, but it is a serious drawback 
 to the larger, constant book-buyers, and 
 must mean that the conscientious reviewer 
 can seek refuge only in “ dope ”! 
 
 The “ Classified Analysis ” shows how 
 the totals for the various kinds of books 
 vary from those of last year. The 
 following classes show appreciable 
 increases: —Fiction (+ 556), Juvenile 
 
 {+ 272), History (+ 143), Religion 
 
 ( 4 - 126), Literature ( 4 - 85), Science 
 
 ( 4 - 81), Medicine ( 4 - 73), Fine Arts ( 4 - 46), 
 and Poetry and Drama ( 4 - 44). A few 
 classes show decreases : General Works 
 (- 68), Games (- 57), Geography (- 39), 
 Law (— 33), and smaller decreases in 
 
 Business, Agriculture and Military and 
 Naval. 
 
 It is interesting to compare the order 
 in which the totals of the chief classes 
 of literature appear this year and in the 
 last pre-war year, because these totals 
 
 furnish a rough indication of the pre¬ 
 ferences of the reading public :— 
 
 (1) 
 
 (2) 
 
 ( 3 ) 
 
 ( 4 ) 
 
 ( 5 ) 
 
 ( 6 )

 ( 9 )

 (12) Medicine 
 
 A feature of the year’s publishing that is 
 not revealed by the statistics has been the 
 large number of “ limited editions ” of 
 more or less deserving books. These 
 “ limited editions ” appear to have sup¬ 
 planted the old “ edition de luxe,” 
 although the terms are by no means 
 synonymous. The post-war taste for buy¬ 
 ing first and limited editions of modern 
 books is a striking feature of the book 
 trade to-day, and no doubt these highly- 
 priced “ limited editions ” are the pub¬ 
 lishers’ response to a public demand. 
 
 The following totals for the last twelve 
 years are also of considerable interest, as 
 they show the “ slough of despond ” 
 through which publishing has passed to 
 
 what we may now hope is the firm ground 
 on the other side :— 
 
 New New

 Much 
 
 further 
 
 detailed 
 
 information 
 
 regarding the year’s publishing may be 
 gleaned from the appended analytical 
 tables. 
 
 A note as to the method of enumerat¬ 
 ing the books published may be useful. 
 Each complete publication is counted as 
 one, whether it is in one or more 
 


## p. (#8) ##################################################

volumes. Serials that appear later as a 
 collected volume are counted as an ordi¬ 
 nary book on the appearance of that 
 volume; so that, for example, the series of 
 “ Statutory Rules and Orders ” issued by 
 the Government, and amounting to hun¬ 
 dreds in the year, are counted as one item 
 on the appearance of the annual collected 
 volume. 
 
 All Government publications do not 
 appear in The Publishers' Circular, and 
 these tables, because many hundreds of 
 them are merely business papers that are 
 not publications in the real sense at all; 
 but all the important Government pub¬ 
 lications do appear. As regards other 
 classes, it should be noted that 
 
 “ Education ” includes only books 
 about educational theory and prac¬ 
 tice, and not text-books on special sub¬ 
 jects which are classed under their 
 subjects; and that all publications of 48 
 pages or less are counted as “ pamphlets.” 
 It would be possible to swell the totals to 
 an enormous extent by counting all kinds 
 of printed matter (such as ephemeral 
 pamphlets and leaflets, local government 
 publications, musical texts, etc.), but the 
 purpose of this table is to represent the 
 book publishing activity of the United 
 Kingdom. This must be remembered in 
 comparing the figures with those of other 
 countries, in some of which single copies 
 of newspapers are counted separately.

 DIRECTORY OF PUBLISHERS 
 
 399 
 
 DIRECTORY OF PUBLISHERS 
 
 Publishers are invited to send us their Telegraphic Addresses and Telephone Numbers. 
 
 Those sent ivill be found below between square brackets [ ], and separated from each other by a semicolon (;). 
 
 The Editor will be glad to be notified of any inaccuracy in the following lists for correction in subsequent volumes. 
 
 This list of Publishers, with their Addresses, has been compiled principally with a view to supplying 
 information regarding the books in the English Catalogue. This will explain the inclusion of some firms 
 in the list who can scarcely, in the strict acceptation of the term, be called Publishers, since the publication 
 of books forms only an occasional part of their business. 
 
 Aberdeen University Press, Ltd., Upperkirkgate, 
 Aberdeen. 
 
 Accountancy and Secretarial Training Insti¬ 
 tute, 28, High Street, Newport, Mon. 
 Ackermann (A.) & Son, Ltd., 157A, New Bond 
 Street, W.i. [Bistre, Wesdo; 6158 Mayfair.]

 Bartholomew Close, E.C.i. [956 City.] 
 Aeronautical Society of Gt. Britain. See Royal 
 Aeronautical Society.

 14, Bream’s Buildings, E.C.4. [426 Holborn.]

 Street, Manchester.

 Street and St. Peter Street, Oldham.

 Broad Street, Oxford.

 Crown Court, Chancery Lane, W.C.2. [Good- 
 ship, Fleet; 4595 Holborn.]

“Will outbid all rivals.”— Bookman 
 “Certainly wonderful.”— Nation & Athenxum 
 
 THE CARLTON CLASSICS 
 
 A SERIES OF BOOKS OF THE WORLD’S MASTERPIECES 
 
 Artistic Cloth, rounded back, gilt top, gold blocked side and back, decorative title page, silk marker, 
 2s. net; Leather, rounded back and round comers, gilt top, gold blocked side and back, decorative 
 title page, silk marker, 3s. net. It is the aim of this Series to present in tasteful and artistic 
 form the World’s favourite masterpieces in prose and verse, and the Publishers believe that 
 these Classics will be considered new and distinctive, and surpass any series at present 
 before the public in the beauty of their printing and the daintiness of their format. 
 Each Volume contains a Biographical Introduction by the Editor, Mr. Hannaford Bennett.

 .CHARLES KINGSLEY 
 
 TO FOLLOW 
 
 Messrs, John Long have now ready their New Catalogue (1924), Demy 8 vo, 116 pages. 
 It is a most interesting production, and embraces books of Travel, Biography, Fiction, 
 Belles-Lettres, Poetry, the Drama, etc. Please write for a copy. 
 
 JOHN LONG, LTD., 12, 13 fif 14 Norris Street, Haymarket, London
